Message: Do you intern at a for-profit company?
Do you intern at a not-for-profit organization?
Do you intern for Congress?
Do you receive training similar to what you would get at a college, school, or another educational institution?
Does a college, university, secondary school, specialist, technical, vocational or trade school oversee the program and award vocational credit?
Does the internship teach skills that are useful in jobs outside of the employer's operation?
Do you perform the routine work of the business on a regular basis?
Is the business dependent upon your work?
Are you engaged in productive work -- for example, filing, clerical work, or helping customers?
Are you the primary beneficiary of your training?
Is an academic institution giving you credit for the internship?
Does your employer derive more than incidental benefit from your work?
Do you sometimes perform the same tasks as regular employees?
When you perform these tasks, are you under close and constant supervision?
When you perform these tasks, do you receive the same level of supervision as regular workers?
Do you ever substitute for regular workers at specific (peak) time periods?
Would your employer need to hire more employees, or require their current staff to work more hours, if you weren't there?
Are your activities of immediate advantage to your employer?
Is your employer dedicating any special resources (training, supervision) to your internship that could detract from their productivity?
Are you guaranteed a job at your office when the internship is over?
Is there a direct connection between your completion of the internship and a job offer?
Does your organization consider the internship to be a "trial period" for your employment?
Were you notified prior to starting your position, in writing, that you will not receive wages and are not considered an employee?
Are you interning full-time?
Have you been working part-time regularly for the long term â€” over six months?
Is your internship for civic, humanitarian, or charitable purposes?
